title: 111_s3004
content: The "Citizens Right to Know Act of 2010" requires issuers registered under the Securities Exchange Act to notify shareholders of any electioneering communications they make. Shareholder approval is also necessary for such communications. Section 14 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include limitations on electioneering communications for foreign-owned issuers. Issuers must obtain prior shareholder approval before engaging in any electioneering communication. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include restrictions on electioneering communications for foreign-owned issuers. Shareholder approval is required before engaging in any such activity, with each shareholder entitled to one vote per share of common stock held. Definitions for terms like 'electioneering communication' and 'issuer' are provided in the subsection. The term 'issuer' refers to issuers whose securities are registered under section 12 or are subject to reporting requirements under sections 13(a) or 15(d). SEC. 4. STAND BY YOUR AD REQUIREMENTS. Rules for Corporations under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 are amended to include a special rule for communications by corporations, specifying that the audio statement must be made by the president or chief executive officer of the corporation. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 amends rules for corporations, requiring audio statements in communications to be made by the president or chief executive officer. If the communication is paid for by multiple corporations, the statement must come from the president or chief executive officer of each corporation. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 amends rules for corporations, requiring audio statements in communications to be made by the president or chief executive officer of the corporation paying for the largest portion of the communication. If paid for equally by multiple corporations, the statement must come from the president or chief executive officer of the corporation with the highest gross revenue for the prior calendar year. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 requires organizations to disclose the top three contributors for communications paid for by them. Additionally, organizations making certain radio and television ads must disclose contributors on the internet. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 mandates organizations to disclose top contributors for communications. Any communication subject to section 318(d)(2)(C) must provide specific information on the internet. This requirement applies to political committees, independent expenditures, and electioneering communications. The amendments are effective for communications made after a certain date. The Act mandates disclosure of top contributors for communications made after its enactment, regardless of FEC regulations.
